Advanced Vocabulary - Page 11

Advanced

Advanced Vocabulary - Page 11

Near the end! Master these sophisticated words that demonstrate intellectual sophistication and precise expression in formal communication.

Navigation

This is page 11 of 12. Use the navigation below to explore all vocabulary pages.

Word List

Ostentatious

/ˌɑːstenˈteɪʃəs/

adjective

Characterized by vulgar or pretentious display; designed to impress or attract notice.

"His ostentatious display of wealth made others uncomfortable."

Synonyms: showy, pretentious, flashy

Category: Display

Paragon

/ˈpærəɡɑːn/

noun

A person or thing regarded as a perfect example of a particular quality.

"She was considered a paragon of virtue and integrity."

Synonyms: model, exemplar, ideal

Category: Perfection

Paucity

/ˈpɔːsəti/

noun

The presence of something only in small or insufficient quantities; scarcity.

"The paucity of evidence made it difficult to reach a conclusion."

Synonyms: scarcity, shortage, lack

Category: Quantity

Pejorative

/pɪˈdʒɔːrətɪv/

adjective, noun

Expressing contempt or disapproval; a word expressing criticism or contempt.

"The term became a pejorative used to dismiss opposing views."

Synonyms: derogatory, disparaging, negative

Category: Language

Perfunctory

/pərˈfʌŋktəri/

adjective

Carried out with a minimum of effort or reflection; performed merely as a routine duty.

"His perfunctory apology showed he wasn't truly sorry."

Synonyms: halfhearted, cursory, mechanical

Category: Effort

Perspicacious

/ˌpɜːrspɪˈkeɪʃəs/

adjective

Having a ready insight into and understanding of things.

"Her perspicacious analysis revealed the flaws in the plan."

Synonyms: perceptive, insightful, astute

Category: Intelligence

Petulant

/ˈpetʃələnt/

adjective

Childishly sulky or bad-tempered.

"His petulant response to criticism was unprofessional."

Synonyms: irritable, peevish, sulky

Category: Temperament

Philanthropist

/fɪˈlænθrəpɪst/

noun

A person who seeks to promote the welfare of others, especially by donating money to good causes.

"The philanthropist donated millions to educational causes."

Synonyms: benefactor, donor, humanitarian

Category: Generosity

Placate

/ˈpleɪkeɪt/

verb

Make someone less angry or hostile.

"She tried to placate the angry customer with a full refund."

Synonyms: appease, pacify, calm

Category: Peace

Plethhora

/ˈpleθərə/

noun

A large or excessive amount of something.

"The market offered a plethora of organic produce options."

Synonyms: abundance, excess, profusion

Category: Quantity

Pragmatic

/præɡˈmætɪk/

adjective

Dealing with things sensibly and realistically in a way that is based on practical rather than idealistic considerations.

"Her pragmatic approach to problem-solving impressed everyone."

Synonyms: practical, realistic, sensible

Category: Approach

Precocious

/prɪˈkoʊʃəs/

adjective

Having developed certain abilities or proclivities at an earlier age than usual.

"The precocious child was reading novels by age five."

Synonyms: advanced, gifted, mature

Category: Development
